section.para: The civilized and well-kept lands of &nation_name; are inhospitable to barbarian tribes. Barbarism and brutishness are frowned upon universally across the country, and many barbarians will find it a challenge to be welcomed or to fit in. As there are no naturally occurring tribes in the valley, most barbarians trace their origins elsewhere on the continent. In particular, they thrive in the blazing sands of &desert_kingdom; and in the gladiatorial pits of &cliffs_nation;.

In &desert_kingdom;, fire-blooded &firepeople; are the warriors of nomadic tribes who roam the desert, never staying in one place for too long as they consider it their duty to safeguard their home and its culture. Though they may feel the bloodlust of battle, many are pragmatists and some fund the efforts of their tribes by working as mercenaries. Others may be outcasts or seekers of gold and glory looking to start a new life in a land different from what they have known.

&cliffs_nation_person; barbarians frequently rise to great ranks in the warrior culture of their homeland. There, where power and determination are revered, barbarians can live akin to nobility. However, feats of greatness must be constantly proven, and one can only rise so high without a worthy tale of one's own. To this end, many leave &cliffs_nation; to travel the continent in search of fame and honor. But for each glorified warrior, there are many defeated ones in his wake, and some among them are barbarians looking to redeem their names in a new land.

As a cultural capital, &nation_name;—and in particular the central cities—holds performance and entertainment in high esteem and demand. One of the central cities, &arts_city;, is completely dedicated to the betterment and enjoyment of the arts, and any performer, new or veteran, will find opportunity there. From frenetic street festivals, to the studious halls of &arts_college;, to the crystalline elegance of the &hitheater; amphitheater, there is no limit to the passions of &arts_city;'s citizens. This intensity has even produced a saying known throughout the nation: no great performer will forever die so long as there is music in &arts_city;.

Even outside of &arts_city;, a performer has many opportunities to excel. Politicians, storeowners, and merchant guilds are all keenly aware of the impact a charismatic face can have on one's audience, and many seek the services of skilled spokesmen. Travelers, far from their homes, find comfort in local song and art even in a land so distant. And a rural life may become grim indeed without wanderers who tell tales or sing songs of grand excitement and adventure.

&nation_name; was founded as part of an Abadarian religious crusade, and its roots are still apparent to this day. Although the nation is not strictly aligned with any one deity, its senate is composed of eighteen representatives from the most influential temples —be it influence through number of worshipers, wealth, or other means. Currently the temples of Abadar, Shelyn, Cayden Cailean, Sarenrae, Pharasma, Iomedae, and Erastil hold senate positions. The temple of Abadar has maintained major power in the city, and from the gilded halls of &abadar_temple; in &law_city; it oversees much of the nation's financial and legal well-being. Shelyn and Cayden Cailean both have large followings in &arts_city;, and their temples—&shelyn_temple; and &cc_temple;—draw tourists and worshippers from far and wide.

Iomedae's temple is the &police_hq; in &law_city; and much of the police force are devotees. Sarenrae, Pharasma, and Erastil enjoy large popular support from all around the nation for their public services and good works, but they do not maintain large shrines or temples in any one location. Many other faiths have worshippers in &nation_name;, and although they do not hold prominent political power, Desna, Gozreh, Calistria, and Irori all have noteworthy followings in various places around the country.

As a shining example of civilization and urbanization, most druids avoid the central cities and the nation as a whole. However, the rich bounties of the land prove to some druids an insatiable calling. Many of these druids do not wind up in the central cities, preferring instead to live in outlying towns and villages, but some do come into the more urban areas to provide guidance or ritualistic help for government endeavors which involve the land.

Whether as bodyguards or members of the national police force, a good fighter is always in need wherever he may be. There is no true military force in the nation, so very few fighters are proper soldiers.

Monks seeking purification and enlightenment through order and community may find themselves at home in the central cities. However, there are no official monk sects who call this nation their home. Despite this, martial prowess and spiritual leadership are valued traits both inside and outside the central cities, and a monk will not find themselves without employment for long.

Although the nation was founded as a result of a crusade, it has grown so prosperous and successful that paladins are not seen as needed by national officials. However, because of the strong religious presence in the nation, many paladins still find themselves drawn here to advance their causes. A paladin should be cautious, however, as in the court room the nation's laws will always trump any conflicting religious edict.

Rangers are abundant in the nation, but less frequently found in the central cities, save when they travel there to drop off goods from the wilderness or to seek out new hunts and bounties. Rangers who do choose to make a living in the city often do so as members of the police or as privately employed bounty hunters. In outlying areas, a ranger will find many places to call his home.

Although the central cities are lawful and safe places, a rogue's talents are nonetheless very useful to the elite of the cities. Merchants and politicians alike can always find a use for someone with quick hands and silent feet. Outside the central cities, non-criminal rogues are less common and most frequently make their livings as trappers or hunters.

Sorcerers may not benefit from the vast libraries and universities of the nation, but they may still enjoy its wild atmospheres and the opportunities provided here. Sorcerers with the skill for panache and performance may find themselves drawn to &arts_city;, while those who wish to put their magical abilities to use to further their own wealth or careers may find &law_city; or &market_city; more to their liking.

The vast libraries and combined cultural knowledge of the central cities are a great resource to many wizards, and none will struggle to find employment here. Whether as part of a merchant's retinue, as an appraiser of magical goods, or a craftsman in his own right, magical talent is always useful in the nation.
